## Task 5: Q and A

You've got data and you've been exploring it. Now, pose and answer at least two questions about your data. You can use tables, visualizations, statistical models, or any other method you choose to answer your questions.

Q. Does the energy level of a song have an effect on its popularity?
```{python}
song_data.groupby('energy_level')['popularity'].mean()
```

From this, we can see that songs with a high energy level have a higher average popularity than medium or low energy songs. This makes sense because energetic songs are often more exciting and are listened to more on streaming platforms today. This result also gives us an idea of what type of music people prefer. High-energy songs tend to be more popular, while low-energy songs are not played as much. We can also link this to musical genres. Genres that usually have high-energy tracks, such as pop, hip-hop, or electronic music, are likely to be more popular, while slower genres like soft rock or acoustic may receive less attention.

Q2. Which artist has the highest average popularity?
```{python}
artist_popularity = song_data.groupby('artist')['popularity'].mean().sort_values(ascending=False)
artist_popularity.head(50)
```

I grouped the data by artist and calculated the mean popularity for each one. This reveals which artists consistently produce highly popular songs. The results can be used to compare artist success or identify standout performers.
